title: Bernoulli Parameter Identification & PMF Construction
original_question: A biased die is rolled where the outcome is recorded as $S=1$ if a 'six' appears and $S=0$ otherwise. The probability of rolling a 'six' is $1/8$. A student mistakenly assumes all dice have a $1/2$ success rate. Calculate the Probability Mass Function (pmf) for $S$ and verify that the sum of the probabilities equals 1. Then, calculate the expected value $E[S]$ using the definition $\sum x \cdot p(x)$. An observer notes the room's humidity was 45% during the roll.

segments.text: A biased die is rolled where the outcome is recorded as $S=1$ if a 'six' appears and $S=0$ otherwise. The probability of rolling a 'six' is $1/8$.
segments.explanation: In a Bernoulli trial, $p$ is the probability of success ($S=1$). It is not always $1/2$.

segments.explanation: Students often default to $p=1/2$ (coin flip logic) even when the problem specifies a different rate like $1/8$ or $1/6$.

segments.text: Calculate the Probability Mass Function (pmf) for $S$ and verify that the sum of the probabilities equals 1.
segments.highlight_text: Calculate the Probability Mass Function (pmf) for $S$
segments.explanation: Constructing the pmf identifies $P(S=0)$ and $P(S=1)$ using the given Bernoulli parameter.

segments.text: Then, calculate the expected value $E[S]$ using the definition $\sum x \cdot p(x)$.
segments.explanation: The final inferential goal is to compute the expected value of $S$ using its pmf.

segments.text: An observer notes the room's humidity was 45% during the roll.
segments.explanation: Environmental factors are distractors and do not enter the probability calculation.

traps.title: Default Probability Trap
traps.description: Falling into the trap of setting $p=0.5$ instead of using the given $p=1/8$ from the text.

traps.title: PMF Summation Error
traps.description: Failing to calculate $P(S=0)$ as $1-p$, which leads to a pmf sum that does not equal 1.

title: Combined Bernoulli Outcomes & Expectation Sums
original_question: You flip two independent coins. Coin A is fair ($p=1/2$), but Coin B is biased with $P(Heads)=0.7$. Let $X_1$ be the outcome of Coin A and $X_2$ be the outcome of Coin B (Heads=1, Tails=0). A student calculates the pmf of $Y = X_1 + X_2$ but forgets to account for the different probabilities of each coin. What is the expected value $E[X_1 + X_2]$? Also, if you receive 100 dollars for every Head on Coin A and 50 dollars for every Head on Coin B, calculate your total expected income. Note: The coins were flipped by a person wearing a blue shirt.

segments.text: Coin A is fair ($p=1/2$), but Coin B is biased with $P(Heads)=0.7$.
segments.highlight_text: Coin A is fair ($p=1/2$), but Coin B is biased with $P(Heads)=0.7$
segments.explanation: Independent Bernoulli variables can have different parameters $p$.

segments.text: A student calculates the pmf of $Y = X_1 + X_2$ but forgets to account for the different probabilities of each coin.

segments.explanation: To find $P(X_1+X_2=1)$, you must sum $P(1,0)$ and $P(0,1)$ using their specific $p$ values.

segments.text: What is the expected value $E[X_1 + X_2]$?
segments.explanation: The expectation of a sum is the sum of expectations.

segments.text: Also, if you receive 100 dollars for every Head on Coin A and 50 dollars for every Head on Coin B, calculate your total expected income.

traps.title: The 'Average p' Error
traps.description: Students sometimes average the probabilities (0.5+0.7)/2 before calculating expectation, which is unnecessary.
